title: New Financial Fund Benefits Cocoa-Producing Families Affected by Colombia's Armed Conflict
summary: Bogotá, Colombia - Cocoa-producing households in Antioquia and Caldas affected by the country's armed conflict will benefit from the creation of a Special Financial Fund to support their businesses. Developed by the Colombian Association of Microfinance Institutions (Asomicrofinanzas) and Agricultural Development Trust (Fiduagraria). With backing from the Citi Foundation, the initiative is designed to promote access to financial products in Colombia's rural sector and offer technical assistance for improving crop productivity.
tag-1: New Financial Fund Benefits Cocoa-Producing Families Affected by Colombia's Armed Conflict
tag-3: Bogotá, Colombia – Cocoa-producing households in Antioquia and Caldas affected by the country's armed conflict will benefit from the creation of a Special Financial Fund to support their businesses. Developed by the Colombian Association of Microfinance Institutions (Asomicrofinanzas) and Agricultural Development Trust (Fiduagraria). With backing from the Citi Foundation, the initiative is designed to promote access to financial products in Colombia's rural sector and offer technical assistance for improving crop productivity.
tag-4: "Citi's mission is to make a positive contribution to progress in the countries and communities where it has a presence," commented Álvaro Jaramillo, Citi Country Officer for Colombia and Latin America North Region Head. "In this context, helping the post-conflict process in Colombia is of undeniable importance. What better way to do this than by supporting rural inhabitants?"
tag-5: The partnership between Asomicrofinanzas and Fiduagraria Financial Fund is expected to benefit rural producers in municipalities such as Belalcazar, Tarazá and Nuquí, where more than 43,000 victims of the conflict live and where cocoa is a product with great potential.
tag-6: "We launched the pilot project in towns where cocoa represented an opportunity to replace illicit crops as a source of income for these families," explained María Clara Hoyos, Asomicrofinanzas's president. "Cocoa is a commodity in high demand in the national and international markets."
tag-7: The organizers hope the project will have a positive impact on families' economic and social situation, helping them overcome poverty. Over time, they hope to replicate this development model in other parts of the country to support vulnerable rural populations through microfinance.
tag-8: "By mission and vocation, we have always tried to articulate all of the mechanisms at our disposal to attract public and private investment to the countryside and stimulate its development. This project is a golden opportunity for us to continue to improve rural inhabitants' quality of life and build a stronger social fabric," concluded Luis Fernando Cruz, Fiduagraria's outgoing president.

tag-12: Asomicrofinanzas The Colombian Association of Microfinance Institutions (Asomicrofinanzas) was created in 2009 to generate a positive social impact in Colombia by promoting financial inclusion. It plays an active role in defining coherent public policies and providing valuable tools and services for institutions that offer financial solutions to low-income populations. Asomicrofinanzas currently has 37 partner entities, among them banks, coops, NGOs, specialized microfinance institutions and foundations that promote financial inclusion and contribute to poverty reduction in Colombia.
